Award.AwardTitle: Theoretical Advanced Study Institute in Elementary Particle Physics (TASI), held at the University of Colorado, Boulder, CO; June 2013 - 2017
Award.AbstractNarration: This renewal grant provides continued funding for TASI, the annual Theoretical Advanced Study Institutes in Elementary Particle Physics, currently under the direction of Professors K.T. Mahanthappa and T. deGrand at the University of Colorado, Boulder. The four-week long TASI summer programs have been held every year since 1984. The aim of TASI is to introduce advanced graduate students to a much broader range of ideas and topics than they normally experience in their home institutions while working on their dissertation topics. TASI has been highly successful in achieving this by providing a series of lectures and seminars on topics of current research in theoretical particle physics and related experimental subjects. Indeed, during their nearly 30-year history, the TASI summer programs have become a major educational experience and indeed an eagerly anticipated "rite of passage" for literally generations of high-energy theory graduate students. Moreover, since 2007, the TASI lectures have been video-recorded and are accessible online. These video tapes form an important "broader impacts" outreach component of TASI, and have become increasingly valuable to the entire high-energy physics research community. Students attending TASI also have the opportunity to present seminars on their current research to their peers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award supported the Theoretical Advanced Study Institute (TASI), a month long summer intensive program for advanced graduate students studying theoretical  elementary particle physics.  Most university groups studying particle physics are small, so the primary purpose of TASI is
 to broaden the students' horizons, beyond their thesis research, and introduce them to topics which are not represented by research at their home institutions.  TASI is held every June  at the University of Colorado.
 Each year, approximately sixty students, mostly from American universities but a few from all over the world, attend about seventy lectures given by about twenty lecturers. Each lecturer gives a mini course in his/her area of specialty.



TASI is managed by a Scientific Advisory Board, which each year chooses a set of organizers. The organizers make up the program, which is different every year. The titles of the programs, and the organizers, from 2013-2017 are:

2013: "Particle Physics: The Higgs Boson and Beyond," organized by  Bogdan Dobrescu (Fermilab) and Iain Stewart (MIT)

2014: "Journeys through the Precision Frontier:  Amplitudes for Colliders"
organized by Lance Dixon (SLAC) and Frank Petriello (Northwestern and Argonne).

2015: "New Frontiers in Fields and Strings," organized by
Joseph Polchinski  (KITP Santa Barbara) and Pedro Vieira (Perimeter Institute).

2016: "Anticipating the next discoveries in particle physics," organized by
Rouven Essig (Stony Brook University) and Ian Low
 (Argonne National Laboratory and Northwestern University).

2017:  "Physics at the Fundamental Frontier," organized by
Mirjam Cvetic (University of Pennsylvania) and Igor Klebanov (Princeton University)).


Content (lecture notes, videos of the lectures, and written versions of the lectures) is available on the Web (google TASI, or go to https://www.colorado.edu/physics/TASI/Program-Overview for more information).


Since it began in 1984, TASI has been an important venue for training future particle theorists. Many  physics faculty who do research in theoretical elementary particle physics   at universities and equivalent research positions at national laboratories were once students at TASI.
